nodes.text: The guard shack vestibule smells like dust and toner. A desk sits under a dead intercom speaker like it’s waiting to be blamed. The drawer is labeled in block letters: RETIRED ACCESS MEDIA — DO NOT RE-ISSUE.

You pull the drawer open. Old contractor badges lie in a shallow tray. Most are clipped to yellowing index cards. One badge has its magnetic stripe scored through, then taped over, then scored again—like someone argued with it in stages.
A handwritten note on the tray: “These are not ‘active.’ Do not create new access events.” The quotation marks look defensive.
Under the badges is a thin sign-out sheet titled CUSTODY (INFORMAL). Someone underlined “INFORMAL” so hard the paper’s almost cut.
The entries are half names and full excuses: “TEMP—returning after calibration.” “Borrowed for audit photos (not use).” “Removed from circulation (pending decision).”
Any of these still valid?
No one answers, because paper does not answer. It only persists. The demagnetized badge has a sticker: DO NOT DISCARD. Someone wrote over it: DO NOT PROCESS.
The badge insert dispenser is an old slot with a faded instruction placard: INSERT — WAIT FOR GREEN — REMOVE. The word “GREEN” is circled twice, like reassurance didn’t take the first time.
Let’s see.
You feed the demagnetized badge into the slot. The machine pulls it in with polite certainty.
[SFX] A small motor whirs. A beep tries to happen and stops halfway.
The light stays stubbornly amber. The badge returns, slightly warmer, as if that helped.
Demag.
The dispenser prints a thin slip anyway: UNREADABLE — REFER TO SECURITY. The paper curls at the end like it’s embarrassed to exist.
The speaker grille is painted over, then scraped clean in a rectangle where a label used to be. A push-to-talk button has been replaced with a toggle switch that doesn’t commit to either position.
Security, this is OLEA field. Anyone on?
[INTERCOM VOICE] This line is monitored for safety and training. Not in real time. Which is not the same as “unmonitored,” just— manage your expectations.
Found old contractor badges in the vestibule drawer. One’s demagnetized.
[INTERCOM VOICE] Okay. So. Don’t use it. Using it creates an access attempt, which creates a question, which creates a file. We are not funded for additional files this quarter.
I’m taking it.

[INTERCOM VOICE] I can’t authorize that. I also can’t stop you. That’s a different form. If you take it, it becomes “in custody,” and then I have to ask whose custody, and then you’ll say your name, and then I’ll have to write it down, and then—

choices.text: Ask who’s responsible for these badges.
Persuade: [OLEA] Log it as salvage for closure.

nodes.text: [INTERCOM VOICE] Historically? Security. Practically? Nobody, because “nobody” can’t be subpoenaed. Formally? Facilities, but only when the facility is in an active state, and we are— we are “mothballed,” which is a status with feelings.
So it’s orphaned.
[INTERCOM VOICE] It is “unassigned.” Orphaned implies duty.

[INTERCOM VOICE] You don’t. You request a replacement through Admin, and Admin denies it because the site is in retirement posture, and then you cite operational necessity, and then Legal asks what operation, and then— If you mean physically, there’s a mag encoder in the admin kiosk area. It may or may not be “forbidden.” The sticker fell off years ago.
Got it.
[INTERCOM VOICE] You did not “get it.” You acknowledged it. That’s safer for both of us.
Log it as salvage for closure. I’m maintaining chain-of-custody.

[INTERCOM VOICE] Chain-of-custody is a legal phrase. Please don’t say it like that. But— fine. If you insist on being correct: write your name on the informal sheet, do not date it, and take a photo of the drawer label. That way it’s “context,” not an “event.”
That’s not how—
[INTERCOM VOICE] It is here. Please don’t make me be innovative about this.
[INTERCOM VOICE] Appreciated. For the record— there is no record of appreciation.
You take the demagnetized contractor badge. The tape on the stripe catches on your glove, reluctant to let go.
The drawer suddenly looks emptier than it should, like you’ve changed the inventory by existing near it.
You push the drawer shut. It resists for a second, then seats with a soft clack like a stamp landing on the wrong form.
Nothing in the vestibule changes. Which is usually how the facility signals agreement.

choices.text: Leave down to Guard Shack Exterior.
Leave right to Admin Lobby and Kiosk.
